question_text: Using the distributed model for SS-AD, derive the partial differential equation for the concentration change of soluble substrates along the vertical direction of the reactor, considering both diffusion and leachate flow.
standard_answer: The distributed model for SS-AD describes the concentration change of soluble substrates (e.g., acetate) along the vertical direction (Z) using a partial differential equation that incorporates diffusion and leachate flow. The general form is derived from mass balance principles: ∂S/∂t = D_S (∂²S/∂Z²) - q (∂S/∂Z) + Σ production terms - Σ consumption terms, where S is the soluble substrate concentration, D_S is the diffusion coefficient, q is the volumetric liquid flow rate per unit surface area, and t is time. For acetate in SS-AD, the production term includes the conversion from hydrolytic products via a stoichiometric coefficient (χ) and hydrolysis rate (k_h X f(S)), while the consumption term involves microbial uptake following Monod kinetics (ρ_max S B / (K_S + S) g(S)). Thus, the specific equation is: ∂S/∂t = D_S (∂²S/∂Z²) - q (∂S/∂Z) + χ k_h X f(S) - [ρ_max S B / (K_S + S)] g(S). This equation accounts for spatial-temporal variations, where diffusion (D_S ∂²S/∂Z²) and convection (-q ∂S/∂Z) govern mass transfer, and the reaction terms represent biochemical transformations, highlighting the interplay between transport and kinetics in heterogeneous SS-AD systems.

original_text.1: The distributed model employed partial differential equations to include both time and spatial variations. The model structure followed the four AD steps and adopted reaction kinetics similar to Eqs. (1)–(4).
original_text.2: ∂S/∂t = D_S (∂²S/∂Z²) - q (∂S/∂Z) + χ k_h X f(S) - [ρ_max S B / (K_S + S)] g(S), where S (g L^-1) is the concentration of the soluble substrate (acetate in this study) in the whole system; f(S) and g(S) are the inhibition functions of acetate to hydrolysis and microbial growth, respectively; Z (cm) represents the vertical coordinate of the reactor; D_S (cm^2 d^-1) is the diffusion coefficient of the soluble substrate; q (L cm^-2 d^-1) is the volumetric liquid flow rate per unit surface area; χ is the stoichiometric coefficient of different hydrolytic products to acetate; K_S (g L^-1) is the half saturation constant of acetate; ρ_max (d^-1) is the maximum acetate utilization rate.

quality_check.domain_reasoning: The question requires specialized knowledge in anaerobic digestion modeling, specifically solid-state anaerobic digestion (SS-AD), including mass transfer principles (diffusion and convection), reaction kinetics (Monod kinetics), and biochemical transformations in heterogeneous systems, which falls under energy systems and biochemical engineering domain expertise.
quality_check.recommendation: The question is domain-focused, the answer is factually correct and well-supported by citations, and there are no other quality issues. It passes all checks.

It correctly presents the equation ∂S/∂t = D_S (∂²S/∂Z²) - q (∂S/∂Z) + χ k_h X f(S) - [ρ_max S B / (K_S + S)] g(S), which matches the original text exactly. The answer properly identifies all terms: diffusion (D_S ∂²S/∂Z²), convection (-q ∂S/∂Z), production (χ k_h X f(S)), and consumption (ρ_max S B / (K_S + S) g(S)). The physical interpretation is sound, correctly explaining that the equation accounts for spatial-temporal variations through mass balance principles, with diffusion and convection governing mass transfer while reaction terms represent biochemical transformations. All variable definitions and their roles are consistent with the original text. The answer is detailed but contains no factual errors or logical contradictions.

The standard answer presents the exact advection–diffusion–reaction PDE and correctly defines the diffusion and leachate flow terms along with production and consumption terms, consistent with the original text. No contradictions or factual errors are present.
